12.text:
During the nineteenth century Britain rose
to become the world's leading imperial power.

18.text:
But how did the growth of the British empire
transform domestic society back home? How

26.text:
did it influence the way in which people thought
about themselves and their country? Did the

34.text:
empire provide Britons with a shared sense
of national purpose, uniting the disparate

40.text:
strands of society in a common imperial enterprise?
By 1815, Britain had the skeleton of the great

84.text:
empire that was to develop during the nineteenth
and twentieth centuries. It had the remnants

91.text:
of its first great North American empire in
modern day Canada. It also had an increasingly

101.text:
important economic stake in the Indian subcontinent
and was beginning to acquire territory in

107.text:
the far east. Sri Lanka, Ceylon and the Cape
had been taken from the Dutch. There were

115.text:
also stations on the West African coast, possessions
in the Caribbean and a scattering of other

122.text:
islands across the world. But compared to
the empire of latter years it was still relatively

128.text:
small. This fledgling empire underwent an
astonishing transformation during the course

137.text:
of the nineteenth century. By the early 1860s
Britain was ruling over roughly 175 million

147.text:
people. At its absolute peak, just after the
First World War, the empire contained somewhere

154.text:
in the region of 450 million imperial subjects,
roughly a quarter of the world's population.

163.text:
Canada had been fleshed out. Australia and
New Zealand had developed dramatically. Huge

171.text:
territories had been acquired in Africa. The
whole of the Indian subcontinent in one way

178.text:
or another was now blocked in in red. Britain
had also taken over Burma and acquired a substantial

186.text:
south-east Asian empire based on Malaysia
and Singapore. It had become the largest empire

194.text:
in human history, but one that contained a
bewildering array of parts; protectorates,

202.text:
protected states, condominiums, crown colonies,
all sorts of territory taken over to faciliate

208.text:
the Royal Navy, the Indian Empire, self-governing
colonies and eventually dominions, all of

216.text:
which had their own patterns of acquisition,
forms of rule and relationships to the mother

227.text:
country. This formal empire was by no means
all of Britain's sphere of influence during

234.text:
the nineteenth century. Often at least as
important as the places actually coloured

241.text:
pink on the map were countries that although
technically independent were under such a

247.text:
degree of British influence that terms like
'informal empire' or 'semi-colonies' are thought

256.text:
appropriate. Places like Argentina and Chile,
modern day Iran and much else in the middle

262.text:
east, and big chunks of east and south east
Asia all found themselves at one time or another

269.text:
part of a British world system. This tremendous
overseas expansion had been driven by two

280.text:
great forces. The first was the trading and
commercial motive, the making of profitable

287.text:
links with other parts of the world - which
only accelerated as industrial output increased

293.text:
during the course of the nineteenth century.
The second was the unstoppable flow of emigrants

300.text:
from Britain, initially fleeing political
or religious persecution but later just seeking

307.text:
a better life, economic migrants we would
call them today, and they were to open up

313.text:
North America, Australasia and South Africa.
From one perspective at least, thats whats

321.text:
most distinctive about the British empire,
the extent to which parts of it were to become

327.text:
colonies of settlement; that Britain more
than any other country in the world exported

334.text:
people. On the one hand, yes there are powerful
forces: economic, political, social, ideological

345.text:
driving outwards from the centre from London
towards imperial expansion. On the other hand,

355.text:
this by no means and necessarily dominates
British policy making, British politics. Acquisitions

365.text:
of territory are sometimes apparently almost
reluctant when the economic and other advantages

375.text:
of interaction with far flung parts of the
world were preferably to be obtained without

383.text:
the expense and the trouble of actual conquest
and formal political overule. So by no means

392.text:
each individual acquisition, each individual
grab of a new bit of territory, can be clearly

400.text:
and directly traced back to somebody in London
saying we want that. Indeed sometimes the

408.text:
policy makes in London are saying dammit there
is so much trouble on that particular frontier,

417.text:
as it stands, that the only way we can get
things under controlor indeed quite often,

423.text:
especially in the late nineteenth century,
the only way we can shut other potential imperialists

430.text:
out is to take physical, political control
of it. Its sometimes reluctant. I think its

437.text:
more the case of the British government picking
up the pieces after some violent military

443.text:
clash around the bend of the next river or
some failure to get trade flowing through

448.text:
a particular area, or settlers getting into
trouble like for example, the British government

454.text:
intervenes twice in the first half of the
nineteenth century in the so-called Maori

459.text:
wars in New Zealand because settlers were
actually pushing their luck. They were taking

464.text:
land from the Maoris having physical clashes
with the Maoris, which they couldn't handle,

469.text:
and eventually Britain sort of reluctantly
I think as Victorian governments are very

474.text:
keen not to spend too much public money, Victorian
governments eventually do send support to

478.text:
places like New Zealand and of course South
Africa eventually and other various colonial

482.text:
outposts when the interests of British people
and British trade and British commerce is

488.text:
apparently threatened, but its often following
on from some sort of crisis. In some places

497.text:
thats the dominant pattern where existing
or desired economic interests, might be primarily

504.text:
trade, might be looking for new fields of
investment, might be looking for agricultural

505.text:
land to settle, might be sources of raw materials
are already there and then political control

508.text:
follows. There are other cases, this is true
for much of tropical Africa for instance,

515.text:
where the existing economic penetration is
not great it comes much more after imperial

524.text:
conquest thats happened for other reasons
and often happens only quite late. Quite a

532.text:
lot of British Africa starts to be quote developed
or, if you prefer, intensively exploited economically

541.text:
only in the very last years of the colonial
era. Leaving aside the settlement colonies,

553.text:
and a quite significant British community
based in India, in much of the so-called subject

559.text:
empire, when it came to ruling over these
societies, very few Britons were actually

566.text:
directly involved. At the London end its mere
handfuls of civil servants. Remember both

575.text:
the Colonial office and the separate India
office for most of their careers are really

580.text:
rather small government departments. As for
the men on the spot, the pro-consuls, the

588.text:
district officers and commissioners et cetera,
these again in most cases are very small elites

597.text:
often an individual, usually a very young
man in fact, ruling over what might be hundreds

606.text:
of thousands of native subjects. Places that
were coloured pink on the map over which the

614.text:
union jack was flying were not necessarily,
especially for much of the nineteenth century,

622.text:
really under effective British control. Local
semi-autonomous power-holders, local resistors

631.text:
often, might well in many cases continue to
have considerable power. Far more areas of

641.text:
what was supposed to be British controlled
imperial possessions were effectively still

649.text:
semi-independent than is often remembered.
So that really effective British control is

657.text:
quite often later than is thought and often
very short lived before the tides of independence

663.text:
started to flow. I worked out that for the
middle of the nineteenth century the number

669.text:
of actual governors of the empire, administrators,
white people going out from Britain as opposed

675.text:
to non-white people they found on the spot
was usually only about two thousand. Hull

681.text:
city council has probably got more than two
thousand people running it which either means

688.text:
that Hull is particularly full of rebellious
natives and so forth that it needs that number

693.text:
of people looking after them, or that the
British empire was really rather lightly governed

698.text:
on the whole. In some colonised societies
recognising and seeking to work with, if you

709.text:
like to prop up, local aristocracies and monarchies
and so on is a very established mode of imperial

719.text:
rule - whats often called indirect rule. Keep
the local potentate, king, cheif, emir, sheik,

728.text:
rajah in place on his throne and you the colonial
administrator the district officer or whatever

737.text:
be the power behind the throne. The thinking
amongst of course other things is that this

743.text:
is usually a cheaper and less resistance provoking
way of ruling a colony than a more direct,

753.text:
interventionist kind of overrule. So the ideological
thing or the romanticism as its sometimes

761.text:
seen of applauding aristocracies whether they
were Indian or Nigerian or whatever just as

769.text:
if supposedly they were British aristocracies
can be overdone. There's a much more hardheaded

776.text:
calculation, ruling through these people certainly
saves money and may save blood, British blood.

790.text:
In the first half of the century British power
had expanded relatively unchallenged. Its

798.text:
main European rivals were much more concerned
with consolidating land on the continent than

805.text:
they were in establishing colonies overseas.
But Britain's dominant position was underpinned

813.text:
not by its superior military might but by
its overwhelming naval supremacy. Battleships

822.text:
could be sent to bombard a port, overawe a
prince or intimidate a local population, without

829.text:
the need for large numbers of troops on the
ground. It was, in a way, empire on the cheap.

840.text:
Well it didn't involve large standing British
armies, but the standing armies were of course

853.text:
there particularly on the Indian sub-continent,
the British were able to recruit large numbers

858.text:
of Indians and deploy them all round the world.
The only time they hesitated about that was

862.text:
in south africa due to the sensitivity racial
prejudice of the Afrikaner majority amongst

871.text:
the white population in South Africa. But
elswhere Indians are sent to crush the emperor

877.text:
of Ethiopia, rushed to open up territory in
south east Asia, they protect the frontiers

881.text:
of India itself and of course when the war
breaks out in 1914 they are sent in large

885.text:
numbers even to the western front. The empire
was a patchwork quilt of extraordinarily varied

896.text:
kinds of territory, kinds of control, and
means of acquisition. Sometimes this involves

904.text:
treaties, Britain establishing what are called
for instance protectorates where the fiction,

913.text:
and it is usually rather a fiction, is that
the local people or at least the local rulers

920.text:
have invited the British in to protect them,
but much more often than not it involves violence,

928.text:
it involves conquest. Sometimes extreme violence,
sometimes, as early on in parts of the Americas

936.text:
and much later Australasia, it involves something
at least close to genocide of indigenous peoples.

963.text:
No project as diverse and durable as the British
Empire is ever likely to be drawing on a single

971.text:
cause. Its possible to identify particular
groups within British society with a particular

980.text:
interest and investment in empire, which might
be economic or emotional, or both, or rather

987.text:
several different groups which might well
have different ideas of empire and rather

993.text:
different kinds of interest. Those who ran
the empire, those at the very top, were drawn

1004.text:
from the same sector of society as those who
ran Britain back home, the public school educated

1010.text:
upper classes. An expanding British public
schools system provided a steady stream of

1018.text:
officials to man the outposts of an ever expanding
empire. Educated in the classics, their character

1028.text:
formed in the rough and tumble of team sports,
these men were trained to be a governing class

1034.text:
and regarded their role within the colonies
as such. I think there is still some tendency

1043.text:
to look down upon careers in the colonies
as perhaps not quite pukka to use a colonial

1051.text:
or Indian term, but that I think quite rapidly
fades as the whole panoply and splendour of

1058.text:
the empire in the nineteenth century is manifest.
To end up ruling an Indian province is quite

1064.text:
a remarkable thing, you might be ruling Bengal
as a governor general and you'd be ruling

1068.text:
tens of millions of people, more than inhabit
the British Isles, so these are not small

1073.text:
jobs. The idea of progress and of imperial
rulers as the embodiments of progress is certainly

1086.text:
there and in some quarters and in some registers
its very powerful and this I think may apply

1095.text:
especially to the settlement colonies the
idea that these, that a Canada, an Australia,

1102.text:
a New Zealand are the greatest hopes for the
global future. The idea that they're creating

1109.text:
new and better Britains actually is very potent.
But there are countervailing tendencies as

1117.text:
well. Some rulers of empire and enthusiasts
for empire are actually explicitly backward

1125.text:
looking its a kind of archaism, a romanticism,
looking to the wild frontier and wild unspoilt

1136.text:
natives, places where a man could still really
be a man, there's a strong gender dimension

1143.text:
to this. This is also a powerful element in
British political beliefs and artwork. If

1151.text:
you think of someone like Kipling or perhaps
even more a Rider Haggard, then this idea

1158.text:
of the romance of the frontier which is a
very much a romance of the archaic, the primitive,

1168.text:
the unspoilt, the undegenerate is also a really
powerful thing. The empire was not simply

1180.text:
an aristocratic construction however, it also
provided opportunities for the professional

1186.text:
middle classes, those doctors, lawyers, engineers
and journalists, struggling to find employment

1194.text:
or advancement back home. Whilst colonial
governors might embrace a rather romantic

1201.text:
anti-capitalism, seeing their role within
empire as that of protecting native societies

1208.text:
from the destructive forces of modernity,
the professional middle classes might see

1214.text:
the problem the other way round. From their
perspective, empire might be both an initiator

1223.text:
and driver of social and economic progress,
helping to being backward African and Asian

1228.text:
societies into the modern world. This wider
sense of mission, of having something to offer

1237.text:
the rest of mankind, was often reinforced
by deeper religious convictions. Most of the

1245.text:
population at this time viewed themselves
as Christian and the churches were influential

1252.text:
forces in public life. Religious faith could
and did summon believers to action and many

1260.text:
set sail from Britain with the aim of spreading
the gospel throughout the empire and beyond.

1268.text:
A drive to Christianize and convert supposedly
savage or heathen peoples can certainly be

1278.text:
seen and helps underpin imperial expansion
and then support for empire but religious

1287.text:
groups can also quite often be sharp critics
of empire and preach notions of universal

1296.text:
equality before God brotherhood and sisterhood
which are at least implicitly and potentially

1305.text:
and sometimes actually and sharply critical
of empire or at least particualr modes and

1311.text:
abuses of colonial rule. Whilst colonial rulers
the secular forces of the imperial state on

1321.text:
their part might well not feel friendly to
missionary efforts at all. Perhaps especially

1328.text:
in Muslim territories and Muslim majority
colonies then Christian missions are very

1335.text:
sharply discouraged and even banned in most
cases. The fear, and it sometimes turns out

1341.text:
to be a quite justified fear, is that Christian
mission activity in Musilm territories is

1348.text:
going to arouse opposition that might become
violent, anti-colonial opposition. When the

1360.text:
Foreign Secretary Lord Palmerston announced
to parliament in 1839 that the great object

1367.text:
of the Government in every quarter of the
world was to extend the commerce of the country,

1374.text:
he was merely reiterating the convential wisdom.
Just as the British administrative machine

1381.text:
drew its strength from the revenues generated
by overseas trade, so too commercial interests

1388.text:
relied upon state support. Merchants operating
out of the major port cities of London, Liverpool

1397.text:
and Glasgow might seek protection from warships
and pirates, the opening up of resistant markets,

1405.text:
or help in securing a monopoly or a license
to rule by charter. Financiers and bankers,

1414.text:
shipping magnates and insurers, what one famous
modern work of imperial history called gentlemanly

1422.text:
capitalists, all relied upon a flourishing
overseas trade and in many cases the expansion

1429.text:
of colonial settlement. It has been suggested
that this group in particular, with its aristocratic

1439.text:
connections and culture, and access to the
corridors of power, was able to wield significant

1446.text:
influence over the imperial policies of successive
British governments. Whilst in theory, diplomacy

1457.text:
and commerce might march in step, at the first
sign of trouble each followed quite differed

1464.text:
rules of engagment. Status, merit, honour
and success were judged very differently in

1473.text:
these two worlds. Lost battles did not break
banks but they could break governments. Trade

1482.text:
monopolies made business sense but political
trouble. Conscripting semi-servile labour

1489.text:
lowered commercial cost, but if discovered
could raise the home political temperature

1495.text:
to boiling point. Within the empire itself
relations between government and business

1504.text:
rather than being eased by a common sense
of purpose were often strained by conflicts

1510.text:
of interest and a deep mutual distrust. Whilst
businessmen might rage against the diplomatic

1519.text:
ignorance of commercial realities, the wasteful
expenditure of colonial administrations or

1525.text:
the petty ambitions of its officers, to the
rulers of empire these unofficial imperialists

1534.text:
could display a complete lack of regard for
the framework of order needed to make their

1539.text:
commercial inroads possible. It was grudging
respect for each other's utility, not identity

1547.text:
of outlook, that drove them into wary collaboration.
Whilst many colonies were important for individual

1561.text:
industries, both as a sources of raw materials
and as markets for manufactured goods, perhaps

1569.text:
surprisingly the empire was not as central
to the British economy as today we might assume.

1578.text:
Even at its height, the empire took only a
third of Britain's exports; with more goods

1584.text:
always going to places not marked red on the
map. For the advocates of free trade, many

1592.text:
of whom were prominent figures in trade and
industry, the very existence of the empire

1599.text:
could be seen as economically problemmatic.
Many people, especially amongst the middle

1605.text:
classes, were convinced that free trade was
in the best interests of both the British

1611.text:
economy and the British people. For those
like the great radical politician Richard

1618.text:
Cobden free trade was about more than just
Britain's national interest, it had wider

1624.text:
global benefits for the rest of mankind. Not
only would free trade bring the peoples of

1631.text:
the world together to exchange goods and improve
their lives mutually, it would also foster

1638.text:
communication and understanding as well. It
was a recipe for peace and prosperity. In

1645.text:
this early rather innocent period of free
trade ideology the belief was that free trade

1655.text:
would bring empires to an end, free trade
was an alternative to empire if you like,

1660.text:
and there's a famous speech by cobden in 1846
I think it is when the Corn Laws were repealed

1668.text:
saying the effects of this would be to wipe
away great and mighty armies and empires and

1673.text:
so on and so that everyone would live equally
in the world nobody dominated by anybody else,

1680.text:
no national boundaries, certainly no imperialism
at all, and this would be the result of free

1686.text:
trade to wipe out empires. Around 50 years
ago there were two quite famous academic articles

1695.text:
one called the imperialism of free trade,
and one called the anti-imperialism of free

1701.text:
trade, and both sets of historians were at
least half right. Free traders were on the

1710.text:
whole against aggressive imperialism as they
saw it, new colonies, new conquests and acquisitions

1720.text:
but certainly not hostile to British control
and dominance in existing spheres of influence.

1729.text:
Free trade usually tends to be the preference
of the powerful in global affairs so its arguable

1736.text:
that free trade enthusiasm in mid-Victorian
Britain reflects and itself furthers Britain's

1746.text:
dominant global position at that time. Free
traders you could say are very keen on informal

1754.text:
empire, British domination but preferably
without the cost and the bloodshed of actually

1761.text:
sending troops in, running the union jack
up etc in far flung places. Whilst much of

1772.text:
the empire was ruled by mere handfuls of mainly
upper-class Britons, emigration to the so-called

1780.text:
settlement colonies was clearly a mass phenomenon.
Between 1815 and 1914 more than 22 million

1791.text:
people left the British Isles for destinations
overseas. Working class emigration was not

1801.text:
neatly politically tied to empire and imperial
expansion, however, if it had been far fewer

1809.text:
would have emigrated to the independent United
States. In the first half of the century people

1818.text:
who emigrated abroad moved almost entirely
because they had to. Still often viewed through

1826.text:
the prism of transportation, emigration was
seen as an alternative to the poor house - a

1833.text:
last chance to rescue oneself from a life
of poverty and destitution. From the 1840s

1842.text:
and 50s, the colonies increasingly began to
be portrayed and perceived, not as a place

1849.text:
for prisoners and paupers, but as lands of
opportunity where people might find a better

1855.text:
life for themselves and their children. Emigration
was to become an industry in itself with an

1864.text:
army of agents and propagandists keen to champion
the greeness of the grass on their side of

1870.text:
the world. Economic advancement was not the
only motivation for migrants, there might

1881.text:
be social and political reasons as well. South
Australia, for example, had more liberal labour

1889.text:
laws and introduced a working mens' franchise
much earlier than Britain. The prospect of

1897.text:
living in a freer, more open society must
have been a factor in some people's decisions

1903.text:
to emigrate. Whether they were forced out
by desperate circumstances or sought a life

1913.text:
better than the one Britain could offer them,
it is difficult to see how the reasons that

1919.text:
led so many to set sail for the colonies can
have encouraged a deep sense of patriotic

1924.text:
pride in the country they were leaving. Once
they'd got there and settled themselves in

1932.text:
I think they increasingly became pro-British
or pro-empire because they felt that in the

1939.text:
last resort the empire would protect them
from indigeneous people and would look after

1943.text:
them in the face of the expansion of, the
Austalians became obssessed, if thats not

1948.text:
too strong a word, by the end of the nineteenth
century by the fear of what was called the

1952.text:
Yellow Peril which was the irresistable emigration
to Australia of Chinese, impoversihed Chinese,

1960.text:
or the growing power of Japan. Who on earth
is going to protect them if its not the Royal

1967.text:
Navy? Although a lot of immigrants might have
thought thank God we've got rid of the old

1971.text:
country they increasingly find themselves
part of an English speaking imperial community

1980.text:
of which Britain is the centre. I think British
imperialism was far stronger in places like

1989.text:
Australia and Canada and so on than it was
in Britain. One little bit of evidence of

1995.text:
this is that when the empire day movement
came on, the movement to have one day of the

2001.text:
year that was celebrated as empire day, it
was always rejected in Britain by politicians

2008.text:
of both sides, and it was first taken up in
Australia and Canada and New Zealand and it

2014.text:
was only instituted as Empire Day in Britain
during the first world war. Before the so-called

2037.text:
scramble for Africa, indeed before the scramble
for territory in China, mid- Victorian Britain

2046.text:
was already established as Europe's leading
imperial power. Yet when Britain was put on

2054.text:
display at the Great Exhibition of 1851 a
very different story was being told. Unlike

2063.text:
at previous national exhibitions half of the
space within the Crystal Palace was given

2069.text:
over to other countries and their industrial
and technological acheivements were displayed

2076.text:
alongside those of Britain. Partly this was
to demonstrate Britain's evident superiority

2083.text:
in the field but also to show that all peoples
of the world could become as prosperous if

2090.text:
they followed her examples of peace and free
trade. The 1851 exhibition was not, first

2100.text:
and foremost, an imperial celebration. One
has to wait until well over half a century

2106.text:
later to the Wembley Exhibition of 1924 to
find an event that would fit that description.

2116.text:
The colonies of course did figure though,
and there were colonial sections that implictly

2123.text:
underlined the economic value of the empire,
a message somewhat at odds with the overarching

2129.text:
theme of pacifist internationalism. Yet when
the exhibition came to an end and the Crystal

2138.text:
Palace was relocated to a permanent site,
in 1854, the Indian and colonial exhibits

2146.text:
were not transferred and the empire disappeared.
One of the challenges for the historian of

2157.text:
the nineteenth century who wants to understand
the place and importance of the empire in

2162.text:
Britain's private and public life is never
just to look at the empire in isolation but

2168.text:
also always to look at the empire in its wider
context. If you read the newspapers of the

2177.text:
time at all levels thats from The Times down
to lets say Reynolds's Newspaper, not down

2184.text:
in a qualitative way but so far as the orders
of society they were directed at, you find

2191.text:
that most attention is given to domestic affairs,
in working class papers to murders and things

2197.text:
like that, and then to politics. The second
most common subject of interest was European

2205.text:
affairs especially when very exciting things
were going on in the continent in the 50s

2209.text:
and 60s and 70s. Thirdly in America, which
was always a very popular source of news for

2217.text:
people in the nineteenth century, and only
very lastly from the colonies. And it was

2223.text:
only when there was a great crisis in one
of the colonies, and the Indian Mutiny was

2227.text:
one of these that imperial affairs came on
to the front page, or the equivalent of the

2233.text:
front page because very often nineteenth century
newspapers you had advertisements on the front

2237.text:
page. I've found that looking at local papers
in Hull, and it was usually local papers that

2242.text:
people bought, daily local papers very often,
that even when the Indian Mutiny was at its

2246.text:
height, it usually only came about third or
fourth in the order of priorities of news

2251.text:
items, tucked away in the bottom of the first
page or whatever. It is often said that the

2263.text:
Cambridge historian Sir John Seeley once claimed
that the British had conquered and peopled

2269.text:
half the world in a fit of absence of mind.
Rather than trying to explain how it had been

2276.text:
acquired the point he was actually trying
to make, was that despite their country ruling

2283.text:
over vast swathes of the globe, the wider
population appeared largely indifferent to

2289.text:
this great phenomenon. 'While we were doing
it', he wrote 'we did not allow it to affect

2297.text:
our imaginations or in any degree to change
our ways of thinking; nor have we ceased to

2304.text:
think of ourselves as simply a race inhabiting
an island off the northern coast of the Continent

2309.text:
of Europe.' Seeley's main complaint though
was that historians too had failed to comprehend

2319.text:
this tremendous expansion of geopolitical
power. They remained fixated with parliamentary

2325.text:
wrangling and agitations about liberty and
were thus unable to understand that the history

2332.text:
of Britain was being written elsewhere. Whilst
we might question Seeley's analysis of wider

2341.text:
society there is little doubt that the history
books of the time echo the story being told

2349.text:
about Britain at the Great Exhibition; empire
might appear but only at the margins. The

2360.text:
main themes in them, or theme, was the evolution
of freedom in Britain, Britain's progress

2368.text:
to domestic freedom, as putting her above
other nations but there no other kind of imperial

2374.text:
implication to it than that. That was the
main thing taught to Britain knowingly or

2380.text:
not, which was supposed to be built into their
sense of national identity, that they were

2385.text:
a free people, and pride in the empire hardly
appears at all, it is amazing how little there

2392.text:
is about the empire. There could just be a
few phrases about how Britain is bringing

2401.text:
the gospel to benighted Africans or something
like that, or there could be downright criticism

2406.text:
of Britain's crimes in the past in stealing
land from the native Americans for example

2412.text:
in North America, there was quiet a lot of
that actually. So it could go either way,

2416.text:
it didn't seem to matter very much before
the 1870s 1880s. Back home in Britain policy

2429.text:
makers and statesmen were often much more
concerned with the European balance of power

2434.text:
than with anything else; its often been said
that there was nothing like a debate on India

2442.text:
to empty the House of Commons. Most voters,
still a minority of even adult men at this

2450.text:
time, were concerned about domestic issues,
bread and butter issues, economic and social

2456.text:
questions. For the great majority, the empire
remained a very remote thing in the mid-nineteenth

2466.text:
century. Working class memoirs reveal lives
of long hours, sparse leisure time and a lack

2474.text:
of access to the printed word. Not only was
the empire far away, it often wasn't particularly

2483.text:
relevant in lives lived by the passing of
the seasons or the factory whistle. At a time

2492.text:
when Britain was undergoing a period of tremendous
economic growth and transformation at home

2500.text:
many people's horizons were very much fixed
on finding their own way in their own world.

2508.text:
Education for the great bulk of the population
still remained extremely limited. Its value

2516.text:
for all classes had been all but universally
accepted by the 1840s, but there was almost

2522.text:
equal agreement among the leaders of society
that its primary function was to fit recipients

2529.text:
for their proper station in life. When a Royal
Commission examined schooling for the children

2538.text:
of the labouring classes in 1858, it did so
on the understanding that it should be cheap,

2545.text:
efficient and not normally take children beyond
the age of eleven. The working classes did

2553.text:
no history at all full stop, there was none,
so there was no imperial history. There wasn't

2558.text:
virtually any geography and what geography
there was was generally just measuring up

2562.text:
their own school yard again it wasn't though
to be a good thing for children that were

2567.text:
just going to be seamstresses and farmworkers
and so on to know anything beyond their own

2573.text:
village, if they did they might become unsettled
and discontented. The ordinary working man

2582.text:
or woman might have been aware of the empire,
or a particular part of it, through the opportunities

2590.text:
it provided their branch of industry, perhaps
through friends and family who had emigrated

2596.text:
or maybe through missionaries generating support
for their cause back home in the churches

2602.text:
and chapels. But such awareness was not necessarily
accompanied either by detailed knowledge of

2611.text:
or a particular enthusiasm for empire, and
for much of the century this situation didn't

2619.text:
seem to particularly trouble those at the
heart of the British state. Intense popular

2626.text:
interest at home in the affairs of empire
might well be disconcerting, destablising

2635.text:
for government and for the rulers of empire.
Increased interest might mean unwelcome curiosity

2642.text:
about the seemier side of what was going on
in far flung colonies. Increased interest

2650.text:
and knowledge might mean increased criticism
indeed increasingly as time went by it seemed

2656.text:
as though it did. Keeping a kind of insulation
between the affairs of empire and the tides

2666.text:
of public opinion at home was valuable and
clearly often explicitly desired at least

2674.text:
some of the time. For much of the nineteenth
century, Britain's settler colonies, the colonies

2696.text:
that we now call Australia, New Zealand and
parts of South Africa and Canada, were seen

2703.text:
by many within Britain essentially as dumping
grounds for the poor or perhaps places where

2709.text:
disgraced minor aristocrats or bucaneering
capitalists could go and make their fortune.

2716.text:
They didn't feature particularly prominently
in the British political imagination. There

2724.text:
had been an attempt earlier in the century
to try and give a more positive gloss to settler

2731.text:
colonialism, with some success, but it was
only really in the last three decades of the

2736.text:
nineteenth century that settler colonies began
to play a much more positive role in the way

2743.text:
that many in Britain thought about the empire
and world politics more generally. For some,

2752.text:
the settlement colonies were merely a continuation
of British society overseas. British ideas,

2760.text:
values and institutions were simply being
transposed from the so-called motherland to

2765.text:
pastures new. For others, however, the colonies
performed an almost utopian role. Whilst Britain

2775.text:
was overcrowded, decaying, mediocre, a country
of industrial slums and satanic mills, the

2784.text:
frontiers of colonial settlement represented
not just extensions of Britain, but a chance

2790.text:
to create new forms of political community.
This idea of a Greater Britain, the British

2798.text:
nation, or the British race as it was sometimes
called, transformed into a global diaspora,

2806.text:
engaged the imagination of those at both ends
of the political spectrum. We have to remember

2814.text:
that places like New Zealand and Australia
were far more progressive in many repects

2818.text:
politically than Britain was itself. New Zealand
of course famously is the first country in

2823.text:
the world to give women the vote, the franchise
was much more extensive in all of the colonies

2829.text:
than it was in Britain. So for working men
in particular for much of the century the

2834.text:
colonies looked an extremely or potentially
looked an extremely friendly environment in

2837.text:
which to be based. So its not surprising that
some political radicals and some socialists

2843.text:
did see Greater Britain as a space in which
a more progressive and more egalitarian politics

2849.text:
could be enacted and played out, and potentially
even one in which the motherland itself, Great

2855.text:
Britain, could be democratised from the colonies,
so if we link all the political communities

2860.text:
together more closely this might have positive
political effects on Britain itself. So that

2865.text:
was one line of argument, there were plenty
of other socialists and radicals who fundamentally

2871.text:
opposed Greater Britain seeing it was the
latest iteration of imperialism seeing it

2875.text:
as negative in all sorts of different ways,
so don't want to suggest that there was a

2879.text:
single socialist position on this, far from
it. Nevertheless, there was quite significant

2885.text:
support. Conservatives supported Greater Britain
for very different reasons in many ways. Many

2892.text:
saw the increasing democratisation of Britain,
slow as it was, and we have to remember that

2898.text:
it was incredibly slow, as a threat. A threat
in all sorts of ways, as a threat to established

2902.text:
privileges and hierarchies at home but also
as a threat to the empire itself. And so one

2908.text:
of their fears was that by giving ever increasing
numbers of men the vote, of course very little

2913.text:
thought at the time amongst the dominant elites
at least of giving women the vote, but the

2919.text:
thought was that if we give increasing large
numbers of working men the vote they will

2923.text:
vote against empire, they will look after
their own interests and that will typically

2929.text:
involve them either becoming or being ambivalent
about empire or being actively opposed to

2934.text:
it and so therefore its important to try to
create a Greater Britain which nullifies or

2942.text:
reduces this possibility. And one way to do
that is to support systematic emigration from

2947.text:
the cities. Many at the time saw the industrial
slums of Britain's great cities as the threat;

2959.text:
as breeding grounds for potential socialists.
By encouraging and perhaps funding emigration

2966.text:
of many poor city dwellers to the colonies
their radical politics could be neutralised.

2974.text:
It was hoped that the transformation of their
environment, the conditions under which they

2978.text:
lived, would transform their political views.
The alienated urban working class would become

2986.text:
rugged, virtuous settlers. Greater Britain
was a very loose term, it was an umbrella

2994.text:
under which lots of different people could
travel and proselytise their own particular

2999.text:
political vision. Its one of its strengths
on the one hand and ultimately it was also

3004.text:
one of its weaknesses, because as it happens
people did tend to end up disagreeing pretty

3011.text:
heavily on what exactly greater Britain was
and thus what needed to be done to bring about

3016.text:
and secure it. So at one end of the specturm
you might say it was an incredibly vague and

3020.text:
amorphous notion where Greater Britain just
referred to the collection of peoples who

3026.text:
regarded themselves as British in one way
or another, who happened to be spread throughout

3029.text:
different communities around the world. So
people who supported this vision were keen

3034.text:
to maintain connections of one kind or another
with British emigrants in Australia and New

3039.text:
Zealand. They wanted them to be recognised
more positively, they wanted them to be involved

3045.text:
in all sorts of economic and cultural transactions
but it didn't really involve much more than

3050.text:
that. At the other end of the spectrum there
are those that saw Greater Britain as potentially

3057.text:
a global federal state in the making. Most
enthusiasts for Greater Britain were somewhere

3067.text:
in the middle of these two positions. They
were keen to further develop political links

3074.text:
between Britain and the settler colonies but
tended to shy away from more radical plans

3079.text:
that proposed a federal structure to coordinate
the different parts of this new political

3085.text:
community. Much as they might have wanted
to see a new trans-oceanic state they recognised

3094.text:
that it was deeply unrealistic within the
current political culture and therefore opted

3100.text:
for much less ambitious plans. Technology
played a fundamental role in all these different

3107.text:
conceptions of Greater Britain, so whether
you were a radical federalist or whether you

3112.text:
believed simply in moderate tinkering with
the existing structure, the fact that new

3117.text:
communications technologies allowed communication
across great distances instantaneously meant

3124.text:
that a sense of community, a sense of belonging
could be utilised to reinforce the sense of

3130.text:
Britishness. So whereas in the eighteenth
century and for much of the nineteenth century

3136.text:
it would take weeks possibly months to communicate
with people by letter who were accross the

3141.text:
oceans in Cananda, in South Africa, in New
Zealand, Australia, by the time the electrical

3143.text:
telegraph reached from Britain to the outposts
of empire, communication was near enough instant.

3150.text:
And this was seen to fundamentally transform
the conditions of politics, it allowed people

3154.text:
to imagine themselves as part of a single
political community. Of course many of the

3160.text:
people who are populating Australia, New Zealand,
South Africa and so on and so forth, are emigrants

3166.text:
from Britain so they already have very strong
connections with the motherland and this just

3170.text:
serves to reinforce them, it allows them to
maintain contact with their families and friends

3174.text:
back home much more easily, it allows them
to read newspapers the day after they were

3179.text:
printed in London, it allows them to share
in the rituals of national identity and so

3185.text:
on and so forth. So theres no doubt that it
reinforces an existing set of national affiliations

3191.text:
to Great Britain, but at the same time there
are complex currents of settler nationalism

3198.text:
emerging within the colonies. Now nationalist
historians of Australia, New Zealand, Canada

3203.text:
and so on tended to see this as in significant
tension with or as an antithesis to Britannic

3209.text:
nationalism, so you get the emergence of a
distinct Australian national identity which

3213.text:
is defined partly in opposition to being part
of the British empire and that may well happen

3218.text:
much, much later in the history of empire,
during the middle decades of the twentieth

3223.text:
century say, but during the closing decades
of the nineteenth and the early decades of

3226.text:
the twentieth century these two forms of affiliation
went hand in hand, they weren't in tension.

3231.text:
You could be simultaneously a proud Australian
and a member of the wider British diaspora.

3243.text:
There were, of course, minorities within the
settler colonies, the French speaking Quebecois

3249.text:
in Canada or the Irish in Australia, for example,
who were either deeply ambivalent about, or

3256.text:
resistant to, attempts to impose or deepen
a sense of Britishness. Even so within these

3265.text:
populations there was occassional support
for being at least part of a grand imperial

3271.text:
structure. The flexibility of the idea of
Greater Britain, its lack of a precise definition,

3281.text:
stimulated considerable debate about who was
included in or could become part of this family

3288.text:
of Britishness. There is for instance great
ambiguity and disagreement about whether the

3295.text:
United States is or should be part of that
Greater Britain, that Anglo-sphere or again

3304.text:
sometimes at the time often at the time a
racialised language of Anglo-Saxonism is used.

3310.text:
So for some people the United States is or
should be part of that global family of Britishness.

3318.text:
For the some people the quote Anglo-Saxon
Germans ought to be invited into it, remember

3326.text:
that Cecil Rhodes when he established the
scholarships in Oxford that were going to

3331.text:
perpetuate his name originally included German
as well as American and British colonial students

3339.text:
in the scheme. There's lots of doubt and ambiguity
and dispute about whether Ireland and the

3345.text:
Irish really belong to the family or not,
and fascinatingly though more at the margin

3353.text:
about whether non-white subjects of the empire
might be or might in future become really

3362.text:
part of the family. The intensely racialised
discourse of so much of public life in that

3369.text:
time tended to proclaim or assume that they
weren't, that they couldn't be, this was a

3375.text:
whites only affair as really in its origins
the commonwealth was. But you do get significant

3385.text:
numbers especially among educated elites in
most obviously the Caribbean, but also in

3392.text:
West and Southern Africa, in Bengal and elsewhere
saying we are British too, we are part of

3400.text:
this Greater Britain, we are part of this
family and we demand the rights which come

3406.text:
from membership in the family. In the early
part of the nineteenth century the idea that

3431.text:
Britain had a duty to communicate to those
subject to its rule the blessings and benefits

3438.text:
of the European condition held a wide currency.
Britain's imperial purpose, it was argued,

3447.text:
was not simply the grubby pursuit of profit
but rather a commitment to bring light into

3453.text:
the darkest corners of the world. Britain
had to embrace the responsibilities of empire

3460.text:
to which it had been called by Providence.
These wider global commitments found expression

3469.text:
in the missionary movement abroad and the
anti-slavery campaign at home; both underpinned

3475.text:
by the belief that the great mass of mankind
could and would be transformed. I think evangelical

3486.text:
Christianity has an important impact on attitudes
towards race and I think there is a first

3493.text:
half of the nineteenth century attitude which
is in some ways idealistic and also rather

3500.text:
unrealistic. I think there is the hope that
as they, the other, black and brown others

3508.text:
become subject to British rule, the civilising
mission, the impact of Christianity, they

3515.text:
will gradually somehow, by some magic, turn
into brown and black Englishmen and women.

3522.text:
I think theres this enormous evangelical hope
that that will happen. Well the sort of highpoint

3528.text:
of universalist thinking, of the kinds of
thinking which was, we are all the same we

3537.text:
can all become the same, and what underpinned
that was that everybody can become like us

3544.text:
that was really, that was what was imagined
in the abolition campaigns. We are brothers

3551.text:
under the skin, and the skin doesn't matter.
But the skin did matter and the problem is

3560.text:
after emancipation when it became clear that
emancipated Africans were not going to fit

3568.text:
quite as easily into a picture of industrious,
hard-working domesticated men and women, which

3576.text:
was what the abolitionists had imagined, then
a sense of disappointment, a sense of economic

3582.text:
failure, arguments begin to emerge about how
emancipation hasn't worked, its an experiment

3590.text:
that hasn't worked. And what goes with that
is new ways of articulating the differences

3597.text:
between peoples that can no longer rest on
you know the problem is slavery, now there

3603.text:
has to be something else, so the problem is
civilisation, the problem is these forms of

3608.text:
barbarism which are still there and they are
of course associated also with skin and bones

3615.text:
and hair and all those things. So there's
a physical aspect to it. But I don't think

3622.text:
that biological notions of race are the key
to it. I think that its a civilisational index

3628.text:
which is really critical. Abolitionists were
increasingly on the defensive over the question

3639.text:
of emancipation in the West Indies. Those
public men who had always opposed the abolition

3646.text:
of slavery now became more forthright in their
opinions. Events in the Caribbean demonstrated,

3655.text:
it was claimed, the essential inferiority
of black people. They were born to be mastered

3663.text:
and had only been briefly lifted out of barbarism
by their enforced enslavement and encounter

3671.text:
with Europe. Whilst the empire's white subjects
might be capable of self-government, those

3679.text:
colonies with substantial black populations
were not. Those optimistic, progressivist,

3688.text:
for that matter arrogant British ideas about
how empire was going to develop were dealt

3694.text:
a further blow by a series events in the colonies.
The so-called Indian Mutiny of 1857 and the

3705.text:
Morant Bay Rebellion in Jamaica in 1865, both
dramatic rejections of British authority,

3715.text:
forced missionaries and their supporters to
recognise that colonial rule was not a simple

3720.text:
matter at all. The empire's non-white subjects
were perhaps less men and brothers, but rather

3729.text:
children who needed responsible and at times
forceful parents. Although there was no doubting

3739.text:
Britain's civilisational superiority, the
extent to which British rule could transform,

3746.text:
however gradually, the races or peoples under
its care was a contested issue. 'Let us take

3755.text:
the negro as we find him', announced the speaker
at a meeting of the Anthropolgical Society

3761.text:
of London in 1866, 'as God designed him, not
a white man, nor the equal of a white man.'

3773.text:
For those who believed all peoples were the
descendents of Adam and Eve, the differences

3780.text:
between races could be explained by differences
in culture and climate. This didn't mean that

3787.text:
all were equal, but given the chance, and
the right conditions, the level of civilisation

3795.text:
attained by European culture might be reached
by all. At the same time there were those

3804.text:
who focused on ideas of permanent physical
difference and inherited characteristics to

3810.text:
explain the fundamental differences between
peoples. These two discourses on race, that

3820.text:
of cultural differentialism and that of biological
racism, were both used to uphold racial hierarchies

3827.text:
that progressed from 'savagery' to 'civilisation'
and ultimately featured white Anglo-Saxons

3834.text:
at their apex. They were perhaps not two different
systems but rather racism's two registers.

3844.text:
There's no doubt that various scientific developments
during the nineteenth century feed into a

3852.text:
set of arguments about race. The argument
can be overstated however. There's lots of

3857.text:
different factors go into making racial arguments
and evolutionary claims post-Darwin can be

3864.text:
used for completely contradictory and conflicting
political visions. So for example you got

3869.text:
social Darwinists who thought that the main
lesson that could be learnt from Darwin's

3873.text:
work was that the races of the world are going
to end up in perpetual conflict with one another

3878.text:
and that the strongest would win out in the
long run. Deeply pessimistic, racist, competitive

3886.text:
view, could also be used to support unfettered
capitalism and a variety of other social practices

3891.text:
and institutions. At the same time you had
people like Prince Kropotkin, anarchists arguing

3897.text:
that the lesson to be learnt from evolution
was that human harmony was natural and that

3901.text:
cooperation was what was ordained by nature.
Scientific developments certainly played a

3918.text:
role, but not for everyone. You didn't, and
don't, need to believe in an evolutionary

3924.text:
theory to be a racist. Ideas of racial hierarchy
had existed prior to the nineteenth century

3933.text:
but had been supported by philosophical and
religious, rather than scientific, arguments.

3942.text:
The growth of pseudo-scientific racial theories
were tributaries that fed into an existing

3948.text:
stream of racial thinking in the later nineteenth
century and gave it new form. Theres no doubt

3956.text:
that at least some people, including some
very prominent people did think that science

3959.text:
now legitimated views about race and human
society. Science has huge cultural authority,

3965.text:
it does now and it did then, and to be able
to make arguments about social life and in

3970.text:
particular ones about the relations between
peoples and between cultures, and to dress

3974.text:
this in the language of science is to make
a very powerful ideological claim one that

3979.text:
is extremely effetive in shaping the way that
people think about the nature of the world.

3989.text:
The idea that certain races, certain groups
of people, were living expanding communities

3996.text:
whilst others were failing dying ones could
and did shape relationships between coloniser

4003.text:
and colonised. In Australia, most strikingly,
interaction with aboriginees was often underpinned

4012.text:
by a grim self consoling conviction that it
didn't matter too much how these people were

4018.text:
being treated because they were a race doomed
to die out anyway. Although the belief in

4027.text:
the essential unity of mankind still remained
a powerful one for some people, by the end

4034.text:
of the nineteenth century the negative representation
of other races or peoples as inferior to white

4041.text:
Britons could be found in many different cultural
forms. If you look at the outpouring of children's

4050.text:
literature the books for boys and books for
girls in the latter part of the nineteenth

4054.text:
century they almost always back that line
up, so do school textbooks by the way. They

4060.text:
back the line up that black and brown people,
particularly black people are inherently inferior,

4067.text:
more or less incapable of improvement. That
they will sort of hobble around in the lower

4072.text:
depths of colonial society and they will do
some menial jobs and they will be useful but

4077.text:
they can never really aspire to the heights
reached by white men and women, thats probably

4081.text:
beyond their capability. And that is a sort
of unspoken understanding which gains enormous

4088.text:
currency through literature for children,
literature for grown-ups even. Look at John

4093.text:
Buchan's, a lot of John Buchan's writing towards
the end of the nineteenth early twentieth

4096.text:
century, in which Jews and blacks and other
people are just written off as, well inferior

4103.text:
basically, I think that seeps into society.
School textbooks talk about the hopeless delinquency

4108.text:
of the freed slave in the Caribbean, they
just write people off. And I think that has

4114.text:
a drip, drip impact on young people being
educated because from 1870 after the Forster

4121.text:
education act almost every child is educated
at least up to the age of 11 or 12, that wasn't

4127.text:
happening before. And they're being subjected
often, they may have liberal teachers, but

4131.text:
the school textbooks are frequently illiberal.
In the second half of the nineteenth century

4154.text:
members the British political elite began
to feel increasingly threatened by the rise

4160.text:
of competing Great Powers. Whilst Germany
and Russia presented a military challenge

4167.text:
to British imperial supremacy, with Germany
especially being very keen to develop its

4173.text:
own colonies, along with the United States
they were also serious economic rivals. It

4182.text:
began to be argued, particularly from the
1870s onwards, that perhaps free trade was

4189.text:
not in Britain's best interests after all.
Perhaps Britain's economic future might ultimately

4197.text:
lie in a stronger, more unified empire and
a series of privileged arrangments with its

4204.text:
colonies. In a more threatening world empire
increasingly came to be seen both as a unit

4212.text:
of mutual defence and as a unit of mutual
economic development. Up until this point

4222.text:
the empire in general hadn't cost the British
exchequer very much. One of the key rules

4228.text:
of the imperial administration had been that
the colonies should be to a large degree self-sufficing.

4237.text:
When a new India Office was built in London
in the 1860s, for example, it was paid for

4243.text:
by Indian, not British, taxpayers money. But
if the expense or demands of empire were to

4250.text:
rise, would the public at large be willing
to go on footing the bill? There were certain

4259.text:
strands within both the Liberal and Conservative
parties that were fearful of a turn against

empire. They were worried there was a growing
